newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AUSTRALIA SAYS HAS TROOPS PLAN FOR OLYMPICS.
newsitem.headline: AUSTRALIA SAYS HAS TROOPS PLAN FOR OLYMPICS.

text.p: Australia was prepared to use its military to maintain essential services during the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney if needed, Defence Minister Ian McLachlan said on Sunday.
McLachlan said using troops to replace civilian workers, if workers became embroiled in a labour row, should only be a last resort in exceptional circumstances.

"(But) it is possible that during the Olympics there might be a circumstance where the people running the Olympic Games decide that they need ... the defence force," McLachlan said in a television interview.
"We're planning for, preparing if you like, to make sure that if we are needed, we're there in the year 2000. But we hope that won't happen."
Australia, where the union-backed Labor Party is one of the two dominant political blocs, has rarely used troops to solve industrial disputes.

The last time troops were used was in 1989, when the then-Labor government used Royal Australian Air Force planes and personnel to operate civilian services to help end a crippling strike by commercial pilots.
The conservative Liberal-National government has been urged by some quarters to use the military to replace striking mineworkers to end a costly labour row in the Hunter Valley.
But McLachlan said the government had no such plans at this stage.
"It's really a sort of essential part of democracy -- once you break that, you start to lose the essential bits of democracy," he said.
